segments.text: We did a lot of practice coastal shooting.
You said you'd shoot a lot of drones and stuff like that, sleds.
Beg your pardon?
A lot of practice.
Practice, practice, practice every day.
Okay.
That's all it was, was practice.
Okay.
Were you eager to get overseas?
A bit.
Because here we are in 1943, you don't get overseas until 1944.
That's right.
The war starts for us in 1941.
you have all this training, I would imagine that being a training officer might be a little frustrating for a man that wanted to, a man who stayed in the reserves during the 1930s.
Well, okay, that's right.
I had my chance to go overseas and my good friend got me out of it, replaced me, and I'm here because of it.
But anyway,
here, and I stayed there until August 1, 1944, at Fort Meade.
And I was transferred to the headquartered field artillery
Fort Jackson, South Carolina.
Fort Jackson, South Carolina, right.
And you were the executive officer there in 1944.
I was executive officer there.
And was that the same type job, more training?
No, this was a combat outfit.
Oh, so you were preparing for Europe?
That was going to Europe, that's right.
And I went down there as the exec officer of the group.
OK, so now this is the first time in your military career
Now August 1, 1944 finally you are assigned to go overseas and now Fort Jackson is a deployment station basically.
That's correct.
He got it in there.
Then I was in the combat unit and we trained for combat.
Here are another breaks that you get.
I was chaffing the bit and talking to every artillery
personnel officer I could talk to about getting into combat.
And of course, they always say, well, just hold your horses.
Just hold your horses.
And my good commanding officer from Fort Sill days was scheduled to go into combat all middle of September, 44.
He was down at, he was over at Fort Rucker with an outfit that he had built up and trained and he would get taken overseas.
And somehow he had accumulated or acquired a distrust of an executive officer.
An executive officer in the
commanding officer got to be just like a hand in glove.
You got to think alike, and squad alike, and run alike, and everything.
And he had acquired a dislike for his executive officer.
And the night before they were supposed to ship out of Fort Rucker, they had a party.
This executive officer got drunk.
And Colonel Mays, you know, kind of like Ford and electric, like to pull the switch and right out it comes on.
So Colonel Mays had him put in the hospital and went down there and talked with the doctor, one of his old regular army buddies.
He said, you keep that son of a bitch in here.
I'm shipping out tomorrow, and I don't want him.
So you just keep him here for a week.
under observation or diagnosis or, you know, how doctors can do.
And by that time, we'd be gone.
In other words, he just cleaned his dirt and in right then.
And he called me, or had his adjutant call me up at Camp Jackson and asked me if I wanted to go overseas with Colonel Mays.
I said, hell yes, I want to go overseas with Colonel Mays.
Nobody that I'd like to go overseas more with.
But here, I'm an executive.
It's outfit.
And I don't know whether I can get a lift from here or not.
And he said, now, you've got to go tomorrow.
You've got to leave there tonight so we can leave.
We go from Kilmer tomorrow.
And he was the executive officer, Colonel Walter Jenkins.
And I'm sure Colonel Mays was sitting there.
He sat there and did this all the time.
Nervous habit he had accumulated.
I see him chewing on his thumbnail right now.
Who's his executive officer?
Colonel Walter Jenkins.
Oh.
Asked if he wants to go again.
Are you sure you want to go with Colonel Jenkins?
Hell yeah.
Let me talk to Colonel Jenkins.
And he said, Walter, the old SOB, and they live next quarter, some back 1925 or 30, see, and
Back in the old Army days, they were old, old Army people.
So the guy that was in the hospital was?
No, this is my then-Colonel.
Oh, I see.
And my old Colonel was talking, and they were old buddies.
Oh, I see.
And my Colonel, I mean Colonel Mays, said, now Walter, I want the kid to go overseas with my executive.
You're not going to get stanged away, are you?
You know you want to go overseas, and that boy wants to go overseas, so why don't you come on and let him go overseas with me?
Colonel Jenkins said, you want to go overseas with Colonel Mays?
I said, yes, sir.
Give him my right arm.
He says, OK. That's all there was to it.
So I had about seven hours to get packed, get on the plane, and fly to Camp Kilmer, which is right out of New York.
And I was gone.
No kidding.
Yeah.
And so there's another break.
See, this history that I built up at Fort Seal and Leavenworth,
Helping you all the time.
Gave me breaks.
And these are the breaks I'm talking about.
That's why I got promoted so fast.
That's why I got overseas when I did.
And so you joined, then you joined the 407th Field Artillery Group overseas.
Well, I joined with Camp Kilmer, and we were gone the next day.
Yeah, for overseas.
For overseas.
And you were the executive officer there.
I was an executive officer there.
And this is 1944.
Yeah.
September 14, 1944.
And did you go to Britain first or did you go right into France?
No, we went into France.
There again, I was brand new to this outfit.
I met them up there and got to know them over one meal, you know, this headquarters.
And, uh,
They didn't know me, and I didn't know them, and I'd just talk and pop it off.
Trying to get acquainted with them, except for Colonel Mays, I didn't know any of them.
And the old man, and of course I soldiered with him for two and a half, maybe off and on three years.
I knew how he thought, and he knew how I would react, and we'd get along fine.
I could see Owen, he's like, shoot.
Kidding these people about what we're going to see overseas on.
You know, all rumors starting, and delivered ships, and victory ships, and merchant marines, and going on a garbage scowl.
And I said, oh, hell, if you want me, I'll get you on a first class ship.
You know, just talking.
And we left Kilmer on a barge, went up the river, East River or whatever it is.
It was driving rain, all of us out there on this damn barge.
It got soaking wet and everything.
Went in at water level and opened door and you could see lights in there.
Of course, they got doors down at water level.
And they had a man there checking names, Colonel
Lieutenant Colonel Gregory Kibble checked my name off, and some fella grabbed me by the shoulder and said, here, Colonel, you go with me.
Led me in to the elevator, and that was the first time I knew that we were on the Queen Elizabeth.
Really?
Yeah.
So the next day or two, I saw these people, and I asked them, I said, now, is this first class enough for you?
But I went overseas on the elevator.
Of course,
We were an emergency shipment.
And we went off somewhere off of Cherbourg, France.
Got on a British liner, a lighter they call them, which is a small ship.
And they took us into Omaha Beach, actually.
That was, oh heck, that was three months after D-Day.
And by that time, the engineers had built up
ponton wharf out on floating pontons.
And we walked right off of this ladder onto pontons and walked right down a ponton bridge to land.
And of course, this all happens at nighttime, too.
And raining, God, it was miserable.
But the welcoming we had, we went up through the
first, or maybe between the first and 29th division cemeteries.
On the side of the hill and we go up this trail in between them.
Of course the first and the 29th, they lost 80 to 90 percent of their people on that original landing operation.
God, I never saw so many crows in all my life.
I told the colonel, I said, this is a hell of a welcoming we're getting.
I remember saying that to him.
But we went into Omaha and turned back around towards Congress.
And Vallone stayed there for two or three days, and then we moved down south and got into the fighting down towards St. Mary Glees and St. Louis.
into the pocket.
They called it the pocket and then the breaking out of the pocket that's when it turned back into towards Brittany.
Now what Army group are you with?
Who is the commanding general?
We're in the Third Army, General Patton's Army.
We stayed in General Patton's Army in the Third Army until
Oh, let me see here.
We got out of there and got up.
What did you think of General Panton?
Did you have an opportunity to meet him?
Well, no.
To talk to him like you and I are talking, I never did.
I've been in a lot of conferences with him.
He was a tremendous person, a tremendous commander.
He was a great soldier.
He was an outstanding leader.
I admired him tremendously as a man and a person and a soldier.
Any wrongs that he had, if he had any wrongs,
were covering up an inferiority complex that he had, in my humble opinion.
He was not too large a stature man.
And he had been bypassed two or three times in Army promotions.
And he had an inferiority complex, in my humble opinion, about this.
He was a vulgar man, but a deeply religious Christian man.
And his vulgarity to me was a smoke screen.
That's my analysis of General Patton.
He was a great soldier.
What was it like sitting in conferences with him?
Well, he was a very, very...
Ship shape is bang, bang, bang.
I'm sure he had briefed his people beforehand, his intimate staff, of what he was going to do, and it was just a laying out orientation as far as his staff conference was concerned at my level.
I'm sure that his personal staff
me and his exec, his jeet, one, two, three, and four, those people, immediate close staff.
He was a hell of a work for us, because he was so demanding.
But at my level, we'd come in and get instructions and pick up overlays, which you operated off of, overlay on a map.
And he was a typical high-type executive.
He says, this is what we're going to do, and pointed out on the map, and this is the reason why.
And the 17th Division is going to do this, and the 29th Division is going to do that, and the 4th Division is going to do this.
And this is what we could do.
And we could do it in so many hours or so many days.
And that's it.
And that was his final instruction to his division commanders and corps commanders and, of course,
I'm Lieutenant Colonel sitting on the back of the peanut roost.
But he was a great soldier.
You can't take it away from him.
And I don't know anybody that didn't have the greatest admiration and respect for him.
He was a driver.
Oh, yeah.
But I've seen him down in the firefights where lieutenants ought to be in.
And he down there called them.
Sergeant, this section chief is telling him, watch it, tanks coming off to the left or coming off to the right, and here he comes through the bushes, get him.
Goddamn, get him, Sergeant, get him, get him.
Boom.
It was like this.
But that was General Patton.
He was a great soldier, a great person.
And I'll say this, he died like he wanted to die.
He's still on tops, and...
He was a dedicated soldier and he delivered the goods.
And I'm satisfied that we got out of that war many months sooner than had he not been there.
And months means many American lives.
Had he not been there.
Because he had the capabilities of
demanding and making people like it.
I don't know what more to say about men.
Now, as the XO of the Field Artillery Group, tell me about that job.
Well, that job, the group has from normally three to up to five or six battalions of artillery.
It's like a regiment.
made up normally of three or four battalions.
So Patton would say something like, he needs so many guns here or so many over there, and he'd tell your colonel and your colonel and give you the word.
That's right, he'd put them there.
And we were an Army artillery assigned to corps.
We operated through corps, but our direction was by Army, meaning the 3rd Army at that time.
And they would concentrate our field artillery wherever they needed the firepower.
he could see from his intelligence that they could have trouble here, they could have trouble there.
And he would send extra artillery to supplement his own firepower.
And that was our job.
His supportive role, combat supportive role.
And my job as battalion, as a group exec, was to keep

my commanding uh commander informed of the status of everything in his group plus the daily contact with those people because the old man has always gone to conference or something and he'd tell me check on this check on that i want this done i go do it and i i know the preparations are going on from visiting the motor parks or the gun parks
I know the supply situation.
I know the food situation, the ammunition situation, everything else, to give him the answers.
I'd go to him and tell him when it was adequate or it was, we had what we called a combat load, which is a day's fire that you carry with you all the time, meaning a day's ammunition.
And I could tell him tonight that we had one day's
Fire, three days fire, we've got a half day's fire.
And he knew whether to build a fire under the ordinance up at Third Army, for instance, we need some more bullets.
Or we need some more groceries.
Or say, how about our PX supplies?
We haven't been getting them lately.
Meaning cigarettes, and chewing gum, and beer, and this kind of thing.
So you were keeping the Army moving forward, then?
That's right.
That's right.
But it was a fine job.
It was a good training job.
And I did a good job for him.
And consequently- Is that why you were promoted to CO then?
No, I was lieutenant colonel.
But you were still promoted to the commanding officer of the 777.
Well, I wasn't promoted.
I was transferred because
The 777FA battalion lost him.
He screwed up, is what he did.
Battalion commander.
And the colonel sent me down there as his replacement.
And so I was still a lieutenant colonel.
Right.
But would you consider coming back, though, to your own command of promotions?
I got a command.
Well, surely it's a promotion in a sense, but you think of promotions meaning a promotion in grade.
It's a delegation of a lot more responsibility.
So I had the 777 FAA battalion, and I stayed there for, oh gosh, I don't know how long.
And then I got the 745 FAA battalion, which was a heavy artillery, which was 8-inch howitz battalion.
And it required a whole bunch more
preparation and work and that kind of things.
What did you think of American armaments during the Second World War compared to the Germans?
It was good.
Of course, the German armament was worn out.
That's a better word than wore out.
They didn't have the maintenance capabilities and the replacement capabilities that we did.
They were good artillerymen.
Their philosophy was basically the same as ours of point targets.
And they were trained to shoot at a point target rather than an area fire like the Russians.
The Russian artillery are not trained in point targets at all.
They're trained in area fire.
And they have artillery divisions, meaning a division of nothing but artillerymen.
They may have 12, 15,000 artillerymen with maybe
500 guns.
And they neutralized an area, but they couldn't hit a bull and maize with a base fiddle.
They're not trained that way.
They don't have that capabilities.
The German army did until late in the war.
Their equipment was worn out.
They didn't have any replacement equipment.
And our basement story
The experience that we had, when I was in later from 777, I got to 745 at that time, which is 8-inch howitzer battalion.
Finest artillery piece made then and now, as far as artillery, fixed artillery.
And we were running, of course, ammunition was a big problem with them because 8-inch howitzers, it's...
Just big.
Just a little bit larger than 155.
155 millimeters is roughly six inches.
And eight-inch high would be about 200 millimeters.
204, 5 millimeters, they called it each.
And we were going helter-skelter chasing Germans, and they ran off and left a bunch of their equipment because they didn't have
Gasoline to hold it out.
Whereabouts was this?
Well, this is in Germany.
This is deep in Germany.
Okay, so we're in 1945 now.
We're in 1945.
Let's see.
But this wasn't in France after you landed.
They still had the gasoline then.
Oh, yeah, they had gasoline then, or they were running short on it.
And what did you find when you picked up their old pieces?
Well.
We overran them, and at that time we were, because we'd broken through and we fired practically all of our bullets, we were on a ration of two rounds per battery per day.
Is that all?
Two rounds.
That's all we had.
We may have had a day's combat fire, but you can't tell at what time of night the hell's going to break out and we need it.
So to keep our guns calibrated,
and keep our map coordinates fired in, we called it.
We fired two rounds per battery per day, proving out the metrological information we got and our survey data and all this kind of stuff.
And when we overran these 88s, we overran a battalion of them.
They were all in place.

ammunition stacked up beside pine trees, and either the general or our colonel decided, the Corps artillery officer or my group commander decided that we'd do our harassing fire with 88s, Save American Bullets.
And you could use those?
We used them, yeah.
But going down there and working on them,
You could have 20 mils of deflection air worn out.
We call it lost motion.
That's the artilleryman's phrase for loose joint, so to speak.
Like this doesn't fit snug, so it's got so much lost motion in it.
You could raise and lower the tube of the gun 20 mils
of lost motion.
No wonder they weren't so accurate.
Well, 20 mils at 10,000 yards is several hundred yards.
Sure.
1,000 yards maybe.
And the same thing in deflection.
I'm sure some of those guns had 30 mils deflection there in lost motion.
They could point this way and shoot this way.
And that's the condition we found the artillery in.
Now, this was late in the war.
But nevertheless, that's what they were using.
They didn't have the replacement capabilities that we did.
I mean, we get a weapon like that.
If we had two or three degrees loss of motion, we'd scrap it.
We'd junk it.
And the easiest way to do that is to lose it in battle.
All it takes is a commander to write a certificate that it's lost in battle, and that's it.
You don't have to mess with it, as far as accountability is concerned.
and you go get your new one.
And that's the way that worked.
It saved you lots of problems and it kept your fire accurate.
Now tell me about the 94th Division artillery, which you also learned your next assignment.
All right.
The next thing that happened after I got
rid of the... At the end of the war, I was the C.O.
of the 745th African Battalion, the armistice, or the D-Day, I mean the...
In May 1945.
Yeah, the V.E.
Day.
And...
But before we get to that, can I change the topic for just a second?
I'd like to ask you a question about going into Germany.
Yeah.
What did you think of the German people when you went into Germany, and how did they act toward you?
Well, the German people, we didn't see too many Germans, because we were in smaller towns.
Any German people we saw were old people, decrepit people.
thoroughly beaten people, kick-dog people, if that's a good way to say it.
Anybody that was able physically moved back as the German army moved back.
Invariably, because we were a separate army unit, we got the least desirable

Of course, they give a division the first priority, and he takes the biggest town to his division headquarters, and your separate troops, or meaning the Army Artillery Battalion sitting out here, and the squeeze of a big goose egg, if that's a good way to put it.
And we may have a little settlement, or we may not.
We've had leased accommodations and a leased of facilities.
off of the land.
And the little towns that we were invariably put in, and I guess we got in some towns of 5,000 people, you know.
But Germany was made up of very small towns, basically, little farming community towns.
Those people fell back with their troops or fled in front of their troops, except for this one or two old men or old woman
and an old man or a husband or a boyfriend or something.
A lot of them put their cattle and all up in the attic.
And he was left there to feed and water the cattle, thinking eventually, and they believed, that the Americans would be driven out and they'd come back to their homes.
And we didn't have any dealings with them except as conquerors.
Was there a lot of hatred?
I beg your pardon?
Was there a lot of hatred?
No, no, no.
You didn't see any.
I didn't experience any of that at all.
For instance, I picked up a Telefunken TV out of a bombed out house or shot up house.
The part of it was still intact.
A TV?
I don't mean TV, a radio.
Sure, a telephone radio.
And of course it had shortwave on it.
And I could in turn tune in to Axis Annie and Berlin and all on it.
And I just, when we moved out of this little house, I just took it with me.
Well, sooner or later I plugged it in to a German 220 volt line.
The Germans have got
five or six different kind of electricity in every town.
Got 110, 60 cycle, and 110, 100 cycle, 220 DC and AC, 60 cycle, and you plug in, you test it on the wrong plug wire, boom, she gone.
But anyway, I blew out a fuse on the radio.
And I went to little old,
We'd call it a... Repairman?
No, no, no.
General Mercantile Store in Old Town.
You know, he carries oil and he carries groceries and he carries bicycle parts and buggy parts.
And I'm sure he carried a few radios because at one time he didn't have any when I went in there.
But he had a Telefunken sign out on his
on his window glass.
They got Coca-Cola signs and Maytag washing machine signs and telephone signs.
And I went in there and had this little fuse about this long, about half as big around as a pencil.
And I went in and showed it to the lady.
She came hobbling out.

showed it to her and held my hand and she looked at it, wee, wee, and she went and got one somewhere and came back and I tried to pay her in American script, that's all the money I had, American GI money, they paid us in script.
And she wouldn't take it.
She just wouldn't take the money at all.
So.
There wasn't much hatred then?
No, no, there wasn't any hatred.
They wanted to incur the good favor of the Americans because they had been told that we were an atrocious army and to hate us.
But that didn't hold water and got to dealing with them.
Down in Austria, for instance, I took over an area.
And of course, I went.
and made my acquaintance with the burgomaster, so you got in a little town.
And I befriended him.
He had some truck there that he'd used in the city business, and they didn't have any diesel.
And I gave him a drum of diesel to do his burgomaster business.
He took me hunting.
Took me chamois hunting, you know.
What kind of hunting?
Chamois.
What are those?
Oh, they are antelope type of animals.
You know what a chamois skin is.
Yeah, right.
Well, he's an antelope.
They only grow in the Alps, the Swiss and the Bavarian Alps.
He ranges up just below the snow line, high altitude.
Did you get one?
Yeah, I got a nice one.
And, of course, I made a nice shot on him, and that word got out, you know.
But I helped him and, in turn, helped myself because I was the civilian authority over this area.
And I used him.
And I just told him what I wanted done and how we clamped him.
a curfew on down, and I expected him to keep it.
Okay, now this is when you were Chief of Public Works in the Utility Office?
No, that's before I got there.
Oh, okay, so you're right now.
That's when I was leaving the 745 F.A.
Battalion at the end of the war, just at the end of the war, and we got moved down to Holtheim.
Austria, and theoretically, preparing to go into an invasion of the Japanese islands.
We completely re-equip, we star gauge an artillery piece, which is internally measuring the lands, which are the grooves in the rifle.
And if they weren't so far away, you'd get a new barrel, see.
And we had stargazed our equipment, and that's a chore.
We'd gotten some new guns in.
We'd gotten rid of all of our high point people, meaning people that had so many months of service in combat.
And those people that had gotten hurt, they got so many points for getting hurt, and they got so many points for being promoted, and they got so many points for a month, and that kind of thing.
And we got rid of all the high point people and got in all new low point men and officers.
And we were supposed to, well, we actually had shipped our equipment to Marseilles.
Our train was there waiting, noticed that a boat was waiting on us, and they'd ship you to the ports because they didn't want you overcrowding the ports.
And our train was there, and I'd fix them
or my people had fixed up my caboose.
Boy, it was a luxurious penthouse.
They moved in some beds in there for me and my exec.
And it was fixed up.
And the J Day caught us in this transition.
So we immediately knew that we weren't going.
And I'd been given the top secret information.
to the Far East for the invasion of the Japanese islands, home islands.

And so, when I got the top secret word on that deal, of course, at the exact moment, I called my staff together and told them, read the order, that V-J Day was such and such a time, and we could celebrate, so we celebrated.
We had a good one.
We picked up a bunch of cases of champagne and we celebrated with champagne.
Every man in my battalion got a bottle of champagne, free.
And every officer got all he could drink.
I'm sure some of the men got more of it because we had some leftover.
But we celebrated VJ Day in all-time Austria.
And it was very few days after that I got transferred from the 745 F.A.
Battalion to U.S.
Forces in Austria, which were in Vienna.
And there's where I got into real staff work, working for General Clark, Mark Clark.
Oh, really?
What kind of man was he?
He was a very fine person.
He was a strictly administrator.
I have no idea about his combat capabilities because I didn't see him combat.
He was a tremendous administrator.
It's 5 o'clock.
How long do you want to stay here?
Well, why don't you just answer that question about General Clark and then we'll go and we'll start off tomorrow.
All right.
I worked for him for, well, five months.
Mm-hmm.
and I was in several conferences.
He was the CG of U.S. force in Austria and he had a general, Major General Brand as his exec and a Major General Salzman who was my boss.
I was the, they called it,
the public utility officer.
I was an engineer and set up an engineering section.
And General Clark either realized or was told to reestablish the communication systems, meaning the power and telephone and trains and all.
The power lines are like our power poles.
They carry telephones and juice.
Now, Austria runs on electricity.
Basically, it's an electrified country.
They have power stations, both hydro and coal-fired.
Had some oil-fired, but they didn't have any oil in those days.
It was all coal-fired generation stations.
And our job was to get those stations back
Working order.
Working order, and the transmission lines in working order so that they could pipe juice to all these towns and to their industry.
Because General Eisenhower or maybe Mr. Truman recognized that they had to get those people back to working.
Sure, really.
And forget their problems and get them to doing something, to working again.
And so my job, General Brand took
and General Solomon gave me my responsibility of checking the power stations in Austria to see if it was running, when we could get it running, and if not, why not.
I was the American representative on a quadripartite level, meaning I was dealing with a British brigadier
a French Brigadier, a Russian Major General, and myself a Lieutenant Colonel.

And I was the key man in that group because we had the capabilities of transportation, telephone, radio, fuel, and all that, and those other people did not have it or didn't want to give it up for this chore.
Let's talk about that first thing tomorrow.
All right.
